page.title: 11The Buzzards
page.content: Coming down from {Wallabrook Head } along the Wallabrook I passed{Doetor {Farm.}On the other side of the brook was a dead pine tree, and perched on one of the branches was a buzzard. I had often seen the buzzards on Dartmoor, but this was the closest I had come to one, usually they are soaring on the thermals. With a mew this buzzard took flight, and skimmed down over my head, so close I could see the individual feathers. Another cry came from the sky, and there was its mate. The two great birds circled overhead, then returned to their perch. Master of the skies, these birds will always be a source of wonder and envy. Their very freedom is an indictment of the prison we put ourselves in. Long may they live on Dartmoor.
